title: Basic usage of the ‘psychinterpreter’ Package
text: document demonstrates functionality psychinterpreter package using Big Five personality data psych package. Big Five Inventory (BFI) widely-used personality assessment measures five major dimensions personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism. ’ll test major features psychinterpreter including: Basic factor analysis interpretation Persistent chat sessions efficient LLM usage Export functionality across multiple formats Advanced interpretation features

title: Basic usage of the ‘psychinterpreter’ Package
text: Exclude demographic variables factor analysis
code: bfi <- bfi[,1:25] bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] # Show the first few rows head(bfi) # Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions and keying print(bfi.dictionary |> select(Item)) Item A1 Am indifferent to the feelings of others. A2         Inquire about others' well-being. A3               Know how to comfort others. A4                            Love children. A5                 Make people feel at ease. C1                   Am exacting in my work. C2     Continue until everything is perfect. C3            Do things according to a plan. C4           Do things in a half-way manner. C5                            Waste my time. E1                         Don't talk a lot. E2     Find it difficult to approach others. E3             Know how to captivate people. E4                      Make friends easily. E5                              Take charge. N1                         Get angry easily. N2                     Get irritated easily. N3                Have frequent mood swings. N4                          Often feel blue. N5                             Panic easily. O1                         Am full of ideas. O2         Avoid difficult reading material. O3 Carry the conversation to a higher level. O4          Spend time reflecting on things. O5     Will not probe deeply into a subject.

code: # Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors pa_result <- fa.parallel(   bfi,   fa = "fa",   n.iter = 100,   use = "pairwise.complete.obs",   main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data" ) Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA fa_result <- fa(   bfi,   nfactors = pa_result$nfact,   rotate = "oblimin",   fm = "ml" ) Loading required namespace: GPArotation # Extract loading matrix for interpretation loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame() round(loadings_matrix, 2) # Extract factor correlation matrix factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame() round(factor_cor_mat, 2) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),   description = bfi.dictionary$Item,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) chat <- chat_fa(   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   # set temperature and seed for reproducibility   params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42) )  print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: "ollama" Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" Created: 2025-11-02 02:59:25.853321 Interpretations run: 0 result <- interpret_fa(     loadings = loadings_matrix,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 2,   additional_info = NULL,   factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   suppress_small = TRUE,   word_limit = 100,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none",   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 2,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   chat_session = chat ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 6 factors... ✔ Factor interpretation complete print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: "ollama" Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" Created: 2025-11-02 02:59:25.853321 Interpretations run: 1 Total tokens - Input: 2078, Output: 6369 plot(result) Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the psychinterpreter package.   Please report the issue to the authors. fa_result_5f <- fa(   bfi,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",   fm = "ml",   scores = TRUE )  result <- interpret_fa(     loadings = fa_result_5f$loadings,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 2,   additional_info = NULL,   factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   suppress_small = TRUE,   word_limit = 100,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none",   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 2,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   chat_session = chat ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 5 factors... ✔ Factor interpretation complete print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: "ollama" Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" Created: 2025-11-02 02:59:25.853321 Interpretations run: 2 Total tokens - Input: 2078, Output: 9711 # TXT export export_interpretation(result,                       format = "txt",                       file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis")) pander::pander(sessionInfo())

title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: psychinterpreter R package automates interpretation exploratory factor analysis (EFA) cluster analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs) via ellmer package. interfaces various LLM providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, Ollama, Gemini, Azure) generate human-readable factor names interpretations based loading patterns variable descriptions.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses sophisticated multi-stage pipeline: Analyzes factor loadings configurable cutoffs Identifies significant loadings per factor Applies “emergency rule” weak factors (uses top N variables none exceed cutoff) Detects cross-loadings orphaned variables Constructs structured prompts psychometric context Uses compact vector format efficient token usage Processes factors single LLM call (batch processing optimization) Includes factor correlations oblique rotations Supports persistent chat sessions via chat_fa objects avoid resending system prompts Builds comprehensive reports text markdown format Includes factor interpretations, cross-loadings, diagnostic information Configurable heading levels document integration Text wrapping console output

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Key innovation cost/efficiency optimization: chat_fa objects (R/chat_fa.R): Reusable LLM sessions preserve system prompt Single analysis: Creates temporary session Multiple analyses: Create one chat_fa, pass multiple interpret_fa() calls Saves ~500+ tokens per additional analysis resending system prompt

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Single Responsibility: R file handles one aspect: - interpret_fa.R: Main interpretation logic LLM coordination - chat_fa.R: Chat session management - fa_utilities.R: Data analysis utilities (cross-loadings, -loadings detection) - utils.R: Text processing helpers (word counting, text wrapping) - fa_report_functions.R: Report building formatting - export_functions.R: Multi-format export (CSV, JSON, RDS, TXT) - visualization.R: S3 plot method ggplot2-based heatmap visualizations S3 Methods: Package implements custom methods standard R generics: - print.fa_interpretation(): Formatted console output text wrapping - print.chat_fa(): Session info token usage display - plot.fa_interpretation(): Factor loading heatmap visualization - Backward-compatible wrappers: create_factor_plot() calls plot() method Provider Abstraction: Uses ellmer package’s unified interface LLM providers. Switch providers changing parameters, code. Structured Output: LLM returns JSON factor names keys, parsed fallback extraction methods robustness.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Multi-tiered fallback approach robust LLM response handling: 1. Try parsing cleaned JSON (remove extra text, fix formatting issues) 2. Fall back original response 3. Pattern-based extraction JSON parsing fails 4. Default values methods fail Critical handling small/local models may produce imperfect JSON.

text: package targets 80-100% word_limit parameter interpretations: - System prompt includes explicit word targets - Post-processing validates warns exceeded - Helper function count_words() utils.R

text: factor zero loadings cutoff: - Uses top n_emergency highest absolute loadings instead - Clearly marked output WARNING - Prevents empty factor interpretations

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: 🤖 LLM-Powered Interpretation: Generate human-readable factor names interpretations using state---art language models 🔄 Persistent Chat Sessions: Reuse LLM sessions across multiple analyses save tokens reduce costs 📊 Comprehensive Reports: Automatically generate detailed reports text markdown format 📈 Visualizations: Create publication-ready heatmaps factor loadings suggested factor names 💾 Multi-Format Export: Export results CSV, JSON, RDS, TXT formats 🎯 Provider Agnostic: Works OpenAI, Anthropic, Ollama, Gemini, Azure

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: can install development version psychinterpreter GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github()

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # Run factor analysis (using psych package or similar) fa_result <- psych::fa(data, nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # Extract loadings loadings <- fa_result$loadings  # Create variable information data frame var_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(loadings),   description = c("Variable 1 description", ...) )  # Interpret with LLM (requires API key set in environment) Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key-here")  results <- interpret_fa(   loadings = loadings,   var_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "anthropic",   llm_model = "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001" )  # View results print(results)  # Visualize loadings with suggested factor names plot(results)  # Export to multiple formats export_interpretation(results, "my_results", format = "csv")

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: Use persistent chat sessions save tokens analyzing multiple datasets:
code: # Create reusable chat session chat <- chat_fa("anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Run multiple interpretations result1 <- interpret_fa(loadings1, var_info1, chat_session = chat) result2 <- interpret_fa(loadings2, var_info2, chat_session = chat) result3 <- interpret_fa(loadings3, var_info3, chat_session = chat)  # Check token usage print(chat)

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses

code: # OpenAI Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key")  # Anthropic Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key")  # Ollama (local, no key needed) # Just install and run Ollama  # Gemini Sys.setenv(GEMINI_API_KEY = "your-key")  # Azure OpenAI Sys.setenv(AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key")

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params() echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none"

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: chat_fa object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: chat_fa object stores: persistent ellmer chat session factor analysis system prompt already loaded Provider model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple factor analysis interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: Cumulative token counts may approximate providers (e.g., Ollama) cache system prompts. Input tokens may undercounted due caching, output tokens typically accurate. Use results$run_tokens access per-interpretation token counts.

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Results — export_interpretation
text: Supported Export Formats: "csv": Creates multiple CSV files different components: {file}_loadings.csv - Factor loading matrix {file}_summary.csv - Suggested factor names variance explained {file}_cross_loadings.csv - Variables cross-loadings () {file}_no_loadings.csv - Variables significant loadings () {file}_report.txt - Full interpretation report "json": Single JSON file containing results structured format. Ideal programmatic access web applications. "rds": Native R data format preserving exact object structure. Perfect re-importing R full fidelity. "txt": Text-based export formatted report separate data files: {file}_report.txt - Main interpretation report {file}_loadings.txt - Tab-separated loading matrix {file}_summary.txt - Tab-separated summary information

what: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function uses Large Language Models (LLMs) automatically interpret FA results analyzing factor loadings variable descriptions. generates suggested factor names, detailed interpretations, identifies cross-loadings. Variance explained automatically calculated loadings (sum squared loadings / number variables).

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
code: interpret_fa(   loadings,   variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 2,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = NULL,   additional_info = NULL,   factor_cor_mat = NULL,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   suppress_small = TRUE,   params = NULL,   word_limit = 150,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none",   output_format = "text",   heading_level = 1,   suppress_heading = FALSE,   chat_session = NULL )

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: loadings dataframe matrix factor loadings (variables x factors) variable_info dataframe least two columns: variable: variable names matching row names loadings description: labels descriptions variables cutoff Numeric. Minimum loading value consider (default = 0.3) n_emergency Integer. factor loadings cutoff, use top N highest loadings (even cutoff) interpretation (default = 2) llm_provider Character. LLM provider use. provider supported ellmer::chat() (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", etc.) See ellmer documentation complete list supported providers. llm_model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b") additional_info Character. Optional additional context LLM, theoretical background, research area information, domain-specific knowledge inform factor interpretation (default = NULL) factor_cor_mat Matrix data.frame. Optional factor correlation matrix oblique rotations. factor names row column names matching loadings factor columns. Used inform interpretation factor relationships enhance understanding discriminant validity. Higher correlations suggest related constructs, lower correlations indicate distinct factors. NULL, factors assumed orthogonal (default = NULL) sort_loadings Logical. Sort variables loading strength within factors (default = TRUE) suppress_small Logical. TRUE, replaces loadings cutoff empty strings loading_matrix output cleaner display. FALSE, shows loadings numbers. Note: affects output loading_matrix format, LLM interpretation always uses cutoff (default = TRUE) params Parameters LLM created using ellmer::params() function (e.g., params(temperature = 0.7, seed = 42)). Provides provider-agnostic interface setting model parameters like temperature, seed, max_tokens, etc. NULL, uses provider defaults. See ellmer::params() documentation supported parameters. word_limit Integer. Maximum number words LLM interpretations (default = 150) max_line_length Integer. Maximum line length console output text wrapping (default = 80) silent Logical. TRUE, suppresses printing interpretation report progress bars console (default = FALSE) echo Character. Controls echoed LLM interaction. One "none" (output), "output" (show LLM responses), "" (show prompts responses). Passed directly ellmer chat function debugging transparency (default = "none") output_format Character. Output format report: "text" "markdown" (default = "text") heading_level Integer. Starting heading level markdown output (default = 1). Used output_format = "markdown" suppress_heading Logical. TRUE, suppresses main "Exploratory Factor Analysis Interpretation" heading, allowing better integration existing documents already appropriate headings analysis output (default = FALSE) chat_session chat_fa object reusing existing chat sessions. provided, uses existing chat session (avoiding resending system prompt reducing token costs). NULL, creates new chat session. Useful processing multiple analyses efficiently (default = NULL)

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: fa_interpretation object (S3 class) containing: factor_summaries List detailed analysis factor, including variables, loadings, significance status, variance_explained suggested_names Named list LLM-generated factor names loading_matrix Formatted loading matrix small loadings optionally suppressed report Complete formatted text/markdown report including factor correlations (provided) llm_info List containing provider name model used interpretation chat Complete ellmer chat object full conversation history cost information cross_loadings Data frame variables loading significantly multiple factors no_loadings Data frame variables loadings cutoff threshold elapsed_time Total analysis time difftime object factor_cor_mat Factor correlation matrix (provided)

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function uses advanced processing minimize LLM API calls costs. Instead individual factor interpretation calls, processes factors simultaneously single comprehensive prompt structured sections optimal LLM comprehension. Key Features: Structured LLM Prompting: Uses organized sections (Factor Naming, Factor Interpretation, Factor Relationships, Output Requirements) consistent, high-quality results Factor Correlation Integration: factor_cor_mat provided, incorporates factor relationships interpretations enhanced discriminant validity assessment Optimized Word Targeting: Targets 80%-100% word limit comprehensive interpretations Emergency Rule: Factors loadings cutoff use top N highest loadings Cross-loading Detection: Identifies variables loading multiple factors Batch Processing: Single API call processes factors simultaneously Technical Details: Variance explained calculated sum squared loadings divided number variables Supports orthogonal (factor_cor_mat = NULL) oblique rotation results Uses compact vector format efficient token usage LLM prompts JSON output parsing fallback extraction methods robustness

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function requires: Internet connectivity LLM API calls Valid API credentials chosen LLM provider (set via environment variables) ellmer package LLM communication

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Set up API credentials first Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-api-key-here")  # Assuming you have factor analysis results library(psych) fa_results <- psych::fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2)  # Create variable info dataframe with realistic descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c(     "Miles per gallon fuel efficiency",     "Number of engine cylinders",     "Engine displacement in cubic inches",     "Engine horsepower output"   ) )  # Basic interpretation with OpenAI interpretation <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini" )  # Using persistent chat session for multiple analyses (efficient) chat <- chat_fa("anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Multiple analyses with same chat session (saves tokens) interpretation1 <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results1$loadings,   variable_info = var_info1,   chat_session = chat )  interpretation2 <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results2$loadings,   variable_info = var_info2,   chat_session = chat )  # Check total token usage print(chat)  # Advanced usage with factor correlations and custom settings interpretation_advanced <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "llama3.1:8b",   additional_info = "This analysis examines automotive performance characteristics.",   factor_cor_mat = fa_results$cor,  # Factor correlation matrix for oblique rotations   cutoff = 0.4,   word_limit = 120,   params = params(temperature = 0.3, seed = 123),   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 2,   silent = TRUE )  # Usage with factor correlations for oblique rotation fa_oblique <- psych::fa(mtcars[,1:7], nfactors = 3, rotate = "oblimin") interpretation_oblique <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_oblique$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   factor_cor_mat = fa_oblique$Phi,  # Use factor correlation matrix from oblique rotation   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   additional_info = "Oblique rotation allowing correlated factors in automotive data" )  # For integration into existing Quarto/R Markdown documents interpretation_embedded <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   params = params(temperature = 0.7, seed = 42),   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 3,  # Adjust to fit your document structure   suppress_heading = TRUE  # Skip main heading for better integration )  # For debugging - see what prompts are sent to the LLM interpretation_debug <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   echo = TRUE  # Display prompts and responses )  # Access results print(interpretation$suggested_names) print(interpretation$report) } # }
